author: Jenny Wiggins
title: Thiess India chief executive exits CIMIC
text:
Thiess India chief executive Raman Srikanth has followed Bruce Munro (pictured) out the door. by Jenny Wiggins ﻿ Construction group CIMIC has fired the head of its Thiess India business, Raman Srikanth, as its new management team tries to distance itself from corruption allegations involving the contract mining group.
Dr Srikanth, who joined Thiess India from Tata Steel in December 2010 and worked out of its Kolkata office, is understood to have left the company last week.
He is one of the most high-profile executives in CIMIC's international operations to leave the company since Spanish construction group ACS acquired Leighton Holdings in early 2014.
CIMIC, which changed its name from Leighton earlier this year, said it didn't comment on "employee matters".
Dr Srikanth's departure follows the exit of Thiess's former managing director , Bruce Munro, in May, and investigations by Australian and Indian authorities into alleged corruption at Thiess, which specialises in contract mining.
People close to Dr Srikanth said he believed he had been victimised by CIMIC management, despite sticking with the company while it was being investigated, and was considering his legal options in India and Australia.
Dr Srikanth was arrested in India on May 9, 2014, in connection with a private complaint against him by a Hyderabad-based company, Roshni Developers, related to civil arbitration proceedings in Singapore.
Roshni Developers is linked to Indian businessman Syam Prasad Reddy, who has been accused by Indian police of tax evasion and corruption.
 Leighton said at the time that Thiess supported Dr Srikanth, and that it had been advised by Thiess the complaint against the CEO was "unfounded". Dr Srikanth was released on bail on May 17 last year.
But an internal investigation by Leighton found governance failings associated with dealings between Thiess and Roshni, with senior Leighton executives believing Thiess had failed to do appropriate due diligence into the risks of partnering with a firm associated with Mr Reddy.
Mr Munro was also caught up in corruption investigations.
The former Thiess managing director was named in a criminal investigation by an Indian magistrate last year.
The investigation alleged Mr Munro signed off on a memorandum of understanding with Mr Reddy promising a lucrative subcontract of at least $90 million if the Indian businessmen helped Thiess secure a $5.5 billion contract to develop and operate the PakriBarwadih coal mine in the Indian state of Jharkhand.
Thiess's Indian operations, which have been running since 2005, are structured as a joint venture, Thiess Minecs .
​The joint venture is 90 per cent owned by Thiess and 10 per cent owned by Minecs Finvest Private Ltd, which is controlled by the family of a former coal minister.
Thiess Minecs was awarded the PakriBarwadih contract in 2010 by NTPC Ltd, India's largest power generator. NTPC said in May 2014 that it was terminating the contract , which had dropped in value to $267 million, to disputes over delays.
Mr Munro is believed to have been unhappy with CIMIC's handling of the corruption allegations before leaving the company earlier this year. Mr Munro was replaced by another Thiess executive, Michael Wright.
CIMIC's Spanish management team has been trying to restore the company's reputation after changing its name and is succeeding in winning big transport contracts.
